dc:title: Population biology of snowshow hares. III. Nutrition, plant secondary compounds and food limitation
dc:creator: Sinclair A.
dc:description: Lepus americanus were studied in the Kluane Lake region, Yukon. Digestibility of dry matter of winter food plants was 40% in the more preferred species and 20% in less preferred species. Faecal protein from wild hares was used as an index of mean food quality consumed by hares. Faecal protein was lower in winter than summer. In the winters of peak numbers (1978-82), some animals obtained food of a quality lower than necessary to maintain body weight, indicating food limitation. On food-supplemented areas, protein indicated there was adequate food in all years except 1980. Since the hare population declined in these areas in 1982 in the presence of adequate food, food limitation was not a necessary cause of the decline on the scale of these experiments. Plant secondary compounds declined through the increase, peak and decline phases of the hare cycle. Phenols increased 2 yr after hare numbers dropped due to new growth of juvenile shoots. Results are contrary to the hypothesis that fluctuations in secondary compounds cause the hare cycle. The proportion of juvenile twigs in the available food, containing high amounts of secondary compounds, remained low during the decline and first year of low hare density, contrary to the plant structure hypothesis which predicts that juvenile twigs should be predominant in the decline and first 2-3 yr of the low phase. Predation is a necessary cause of the hare cycle and in some circumstances, it may be the only cause. The hare cycle is constant in period but variable in amplitude. Food limitation may occur as a consequence of high amplitude rather than a cause of it. -from Authors

dc:title: The impact of predation on boreal tetraonids during vole cycles: an experimental study
dc:creator: Marcstrom V.
dc:description: When predators were killed, tetraonid brood sizes averaged 5.52 in August, and 77% of hens had chicks. When predator were not killed, broods averaged 3.29 chicks and 59% of hens had chicks. Counts of adult capercaillie Tetrao urogallus and black grouse T. tetrix during July and August increased by 56-80% after 2 yr of predator removal. Counts at leks increased by 166-174%. Removing foxes Vulpes vulpes and martens Martes martes had no significant effect on vole abundance during two 4-yr cycles. When predators were not removed, tetraonid brood sizes and the proportion of females that bred successfully were each positively correlated with vole abundance in summer. There were most chicks per adult hen when vole numbers were high and increasing slowly from summer to autumn. When foxes and martens were killed, neither brood size nor subsequent adult numbers were significantly correlated with vole abundance in summer, although losses of whole broods increased slightly when vole numbers grew most rapidly from summer to autumn. Large vole populations thus resulted in large autumn grouse populations mainly because they reduced predation on breeding grouse. Vole numbers and increase rates associated with high grouse breeding success in one summer were also associated with low counts of adult grouse the next year, and thus with an increase in grouse losses from one summer to the next. -from Authors

dc:title: Arthropod guild structure during early old field succession in a new and old world site
dc:creator: Hendrix S.
dc:description: The Old World site was at Silwood Park Berkshire, UK; the New World site was in Johnson County, Iowa. Both sites were rapidly colonized by all 6 guilds, but phytophages and "tourists' were dominant. Generally, abundance of arthropods in all guilds was greater at the Old World site. Vegetation at the New World site was considerably more complex, and when arthropod abundance was weighted with a measure of vegetation structure differences between sites was accentuated. The relatively low abundance of arthropods, especially phytophages, at the New World site is likely to be due to the dominance of the plant community by introduced species. Taxonomic composition of the phytophage guild varied considerably between sites, reflecting differences in the species and life-form composition of the plant communities. The percentage distribution of arthropods in the different guilds indicates greater constancy of guild structure within sites than between. -from Authors

dc:title: Foraging behaviour in four sympatric cormorants
dc:creator: Wilson R.
dc:description: Air-breathing aquatic animals that feed on benthic prey should attempt to maximize bottom time with respect to transit time between the water's surface and the bottom and recovery time. The foraging behaviour of white-breasted Phalacrocorax carbo, bank P. neglectus, cape P. capensis and crowned P. coronatus cormorants was studied. Durations of dive were proportional to water depth in all species, but time spent searching for prey on the sea bed increased with water depth (transit time) in crowned and cape cormorants, and was apparently independent of water depth in bank and white-breasted cormorants. Theoretically, time spent at the water's surface recovering from dives is critical in determining the relationship between bottom time and depth. At given depths, distribution of bottom times was normal for white-breasted, bank and crowned cormorants but positively skewed for cape cormorants. This might be explained by differential prey densities. Cormorants foraged along the sea bed at mean speeds of 0.3-1.45 ms-1. Foraging speed was dependent on bottom topography and, in white-breasted cormorants, positively correlated with depth. -from Authors

dc:title: Reproductive success of natterjack toads Bufo calamita in two contrasting habitats
dc:creator: Banks B.
dc:description: Adult natterjack population density and toadlet production per 100 m2 of breeding water were substantially higher (5-fold and 2-9-fold, respectively) on a eutrophic (dune) habitat than on an oligotrophic (heathland) study site. Key factors in mortality during development were desiccation of shallow, natural dune slacks and saltmarsh pools and predation of tadpoles by invertebrates in all pool types. Developmental failure of spawn was caused primarily by Saprolegnia infestation at low temperatures or by pH <6. Metamorphic success was correlated with high tadpole growth rates. These rates were determined primarily by temperature and food supply, and the latter was a function of water chemistry. Tadpoles grew faster in the more eutrophic pools, though low pH reduced growth rates irrespective of food supply. Major predators of natterjack larvae were dytiscid water beetles; others of significance included Notonecta species, Odonata larvae and newt Triturus cristatus. Toadlet production varied inversely with respect to numbers of invertebrate predators in the breeding pools; these in turn varied as a function of pond permanence. Deeper artificial pools exhibited lower tadpole mortality from desiccation but correspondingly higher mortality from invertebrate predation. -from Authors

dc:title: Functional response of a small mammalian herbivore: the disc equation revisited
dc:creator: Lundberg P.
dc:description: A laboratory study of bank voles Clethrionomys glareolus feeding on willow shoots during winter showed a decelerating (Type II) functional response of the voles to increasing shoot density. The "disc' equation showed the best fit to the data with respect to number of shoots attacked. The disc equation and the "random parasitoid' equation showed equally good fit to the data with respect to biomass consumption. In no case could the "random predator' equation produce realistic estimates of handling time. The predator mode of foraging is an inappropriate way of modelling many herbivore foraging patterns. -from Author

dc:title: Demographic characteristics of the stored-products moth Cadra cautella
dc:creator: Gordon D.
dc:description: Duration of the egg and pupal stages was constant and independent of the density of any other stage. Larval mortality and stage duration increased with increasing larval density. Larval mortality appeared to be due to starvation as a result of food exhaustion, with total larval mortality being determined by the effects of larval density on the time at which food exhaustion occurred. Increased larval stage duration with increasing density resulted from effects of starvation and effects of larval density on larval growth rates. The density at which larvae were reared influenced imago weight at emergence. Imago fertility and life-span decreased with increases in the density at which larvae were reared. Imago density had little effect on either imago life-span or fertility. Survival of eggs and 1st instar larvae was significantly reduced when they were reared in the presence of larvae dune to cannibalism. -from Authors

dc:title: Control of fecundity in Pieris rapae. V. Comparisons between populations
dc:creator: Gilbert N.
dc:description: Australian, British, Canadian, French, Italian and Spanish P. rapae have the same temperature thresholds, development rates and pupal weights: but there are intrinsic differences between populations for adaptation to host plants, and for timing of entry into (and emergence from) diapause. In insects, the temperature thresholds and heat requirements for development and for postdiapause emergence, obey general rules. The empirical results, in this and previous papers, contradict the orthodox theory of natural selection, which considers only the genetic variation between individuals. An extended theory, incorporating a 2nd level of genetic variation, accounts for the ecological observations and for the widespread occurrence of sexual reproduction. -from Author

dc:title: Population dynamics and adaptive sexual strategies in a brackish water crustacean, Gammarus duebeni
dc:creator: Naylor C.
dc:description: Males are produced in long day photoperiods and females in short days. Populations are characterized by fluctuating sex ratios and marked sexual size dimorphism. Males are always larger than the female they carry in precopula. The life cycle of G. duebeni in N England is annual and is restricted by temperature. Overwintering adults breed early in the year and die by August. Generations do not overlap. Sex ratio during breeding is female biased, then becomes male biased due to massive recruitment of young males early in the year. Recruitment late in the year is exclusively female. Sex ratio changes are due to sex differential production rather than differences in growth or mortality. Larger females produce more eggs and larger males are paired with larger females, but because of the mating pattern, males benefit relatively more from large size than do females. Early produced animals have a long growth period and will be large in the next year; they maximize fitness by becoming male. Late animals are growth restricted and minimize loss of fitness by becoming female. -from Authors

dc:title: Host effects on functional and ovipositional responses of Bracon hebetor
dc:creator: Taylor A.
dc:description: Describes the effects of host species (Anagasta kuhniella and Plodia interpunctella: Lepidoptera, Pyralidae) and size on the "functional' and "ovipositional' responses of the gregarious parasitoid Bracon hebetor (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) and its preferences between these host types. Attack rates followed a Type II functional response, with strong interference among parasitoids, but both number of hosts oviposited on per wasp and number of eggs laid per wasp were essentially independent of host and wasp densities. There were no significant differences in the response to different sizes of a given host species. There were also not any significant preferences between host sizes, though there was a trend towards preference for the larger, more suitable hosts. The "handling time' for A. kuhniella was greater than for P. interpunctella, and there was an active preference for attacking the latter; both results may be due to the defensive writhing of the former species. More eggs were laid on each parasitized A. kuhniella, which are larger and so can support more larvae, but there were no differences in the numbers of each species oviposited on. -from Author

dc:title: Field studies and experiments on distribution and foraging of pied and malachite kingfishers at Lake Nakuru (Kenya)
dc:creator: Reyer H.
dc:description: Fishing behaviour and distribution of pied (PK) Ceryle rudis and malachite kingfishers (MK) Alcedo cristata in time and space were studied in relation to 2 food conditions, 5 water conditions and 6 vegetation parameters. Fish density was the most important ecological parameter. In the field and in captivity, both species were equally attracted to high densities, but (reflecting their 2.6 time higher energy requirements) the bigger PKs took fish 2.4 times heavier than those of MKs. With the exception of depth, water conditions had little or no influence on either species, except outside the range occurring naturally in the field. In parts of their territories, characterized by dense vegetation, MKs tended to spend less time and had less success than in more open and uniform areas. -from Authors

dc:title: Foraging abilities and niche breadths of two percids, Perca fluviatilis and Gymnocephalus cernua, under different environmental conditions
dc:creator: Bergman E.
dc:description: Maximal capture rate of perch was higher than that of ruffe. Capture rates of both species decreased with decreasing light intensity, this being more pronounced for perch. Swimming speeds of perch and ruffe also decreased with decreasing light intensity, whereas attack success only decreased for perch. Ruffe spent more time close to the bottom than perch. Perch were absent from the deepest, darkest regions of lakes, but were otherwise abundant both in the open water and benthic habitats. Ruffe were present in both the light and dark regions of lakes, but were only abundant in the benthic habitat. The niche breadths of perch and ruffe differ with respect to temperature, light intensity and distance from bottom, providing evidence for complementary niche breadths. -from Author

dc:title: Factors affecting breeding success of peregrines in south Scotland
dc:creator: Mearns R.
dc:description: During 1974-82, Falco peregrinus in S Scotland produced an annual average of 1.15 young per territorial pair, between 0.60-1.45 in different years. Heavy rain in May lowered productivity by reducing hunting success and by soaking exposed nests. Early clutches, begun before mid-April, were larger and more successful than later ones. All pairs nested on cliffs; the few large cliffs were preferred, so that, as the population grew, more pairs used small cliffs. Cliff height and accessibility to human egg collectors influenced nesting success, as did exposure. Nests in recesses were most successful. Performance improved as females aged; laying became progressively earlier and clutches progressively larger, from 1 to 5+ yr. Despite some slight eggshell thinning (attributed to DDE), organochlorine residues had at most a small impact on productivity in the years concerned. Overall density of breeding peregrines more than doubled during the 9 yr study, and also varied between different parts of the study area. But over the range of densities observed no density-dependent depression of breeding success occurred. -from Authors

dc:title: Sex-specific energy requirements of great-tailed grackle (Quiscalus mexicanus) nestlings
dc:creator: Teather K.
dc:description: Oxygen and food consumption of 4-11 day-old male and female great-tailed grackles were monitored. At 12 days post-hatching, female mass was 65.7% that of males, while female energy requirements over the 12 day period were 1181 kJ or 83% those of males. Thus, while male nestlings required more energy absolutely, female nestlings required proportionately more energy per unit body mass. There was no evidence that adults compensated for energy requirement differences of offspring by bringing male nestlings larger or more nutritious prey items. Sons are thus more costly to rear. Cases of differential mortality of male and female offspring are due to males suffering higher starvation when food is scarce. Biased sex ratios at fledging probably result from the cost to males of increased size due to sexual selection. -from Authors

dc:title: Adaptive significance of asynchronous hatching in the shag: a test of the brood reduction hypothesis
dc:creator: Amundsen T.
dc:description: Mean hatching spread for Phalacrocorax aristotelis broods of 3 was 2.8 days. By interchanging newly hatched chicks between nests, synchronous (hatching spread 0-1 days), asynchronous (3 days) and "double-asynchronous' (5-7 days) experimental broods were established. In control nests, the hatching spread was 1-4 days. Fledging success and fledgling weights of asynchronous broods were not higher than those of synchronous ones. In "double-asynchronous' broods, last-hatched chicks suffered a reduced growth rate and a higher mortality rate compared to those from broods with a natural degree of asynchrony. Results suggest that the brood reduction hypothesis does not provide a valid explanation for hatching asynchrony in general. Nest failure, sibling rivalry reduction and peak load reduction do not seem to apply in the case of the shag. Factors of possible importance for hatching asynchrony are selection pressures during the egg-laying period (egg-predation, thermal stress, defence of nest), and effects of post-fledging or adult survival rates. -from Authors

dc:title: Host-plant specificity in the cactophilic Drosophila mulleri species complex
dc:creator: Ruiz A.
dc:description: Jaenike's model of optimal oviposition behaviour in phytophagous insects was tested in a guild of 4 closely-related cactophilic Drosophila species (D. mojavensis, D. arizonensis, D. aldrichi and an undescribed form from Navojoa). Rearing records from Sonora and N Sinaloa (NW Mexico) showed a sharp niche separation between species breeding on Opuntia (prickly pear) and those breeding on Stenocereus (columnar cacti). The suitabilities of 4 host-plants were assessed by measuring fitness traits (viability, development time and thorax size) on fermented cactus. Results are in good agreement with the expected predictions of the model in that the resident species had higher overall fitness on its own host-plant. The shift in host-plant use from opuntias to columnars during the evolution of these flies must have entailed a loss of fitness which could have occurred in isolation under stressful environmental conditions. -from Authors

dc:title: Community structure, distribution and population dynamics of Entomobryidae (Collembola)
dc:creator: Vegter J.J.
dc:description: Entomobryids were sampled in 8 woodland habitats, differing in soil and litter type. Ranked abundance curves for each community type were approximately linear on a semi-log scale. Evenness was highest in the youngest woodland which was situated in a polder. In older mainland habitats the 1st 3 species in the sequence showed a more extreme pattern of dominance. Population density of hygric Tomocerus species was lowest in woodlands with more heterogeneous moisture regimes whereas population density of the drought-tolerant Orchesella cincta was high in these areas. Degree of spatial aggregation of a species appeared to be unrelated to its drought sensitivity or to spatial heterogeneity in moisture regime of the habitat, but in general depended on population density. Intensity of temporal fluctuations in population number was density-dependent and unrelated to environmental heterogeneity. -Authors

dc:title: Estimating primate densities from transects in a West African rain forest: a comparison of techniques
dc:creator: Whitesides G.
dc:description: Assessed the densities of social groups of 7 diurnal primate species (sooty mangabey Cercocebus atys, diana monkey Cercocebus diana, Campbell's monkey Cercopithecus campbelli, lesser spot-nose monkey Cercopithecus petaurista, red colobus Procolobus badius, olive colobus Procolobus verus, black-and-white colobus Colobus polykomos) resident on Tiwai Island, Sierra Leone. A modified standard species-specific strip-width estimation technique was applied to data from 28 single-observer transect samples, each 6 km in length. A 2nd method employed 17 sweep samples where 2 observers simultaneously walked parallel transects 100 m apart and 1 km in length. This method used both sightings and localization of vocalizations for density estimation. A 2nd method transformed sighting rates from the single-observer samples into density estimates by incorporating sighting rates and densities from sweep samples into calibration factors. Long-term data on home-range size and overlap were used to estimate density for 3 species for which there was sufficient data. A 5th method used the hazard-rate model of Hayes & Buckland (1983) which involved transforming estimates of distance to the first sighted individual into estimates of distance to the group centre. The rank orders by species of density estimates produced by all analytical techniques were identicial except for the sweep-quadrat method. There were no significant differences among density estimates produced by different analytical methods, except for the C. diana density produced by the sweep samples. Use of both relatively long single-transect samples and also more localized multi-observer sweep samples is recommended. These techniques allow use of a variety of analytical methods. -from Authors

dc:title: Recruitment and maternal age in lesser snow geese Chen caerulescens caerulescens
dc:creator: Ratcliffe L.
dc:description: At La Perouse Bay, near Churchill, Manitoba a significantly greater proportion of offspring were recruited from mothers aged 5-7 yr than from younger (-4 yr) or older (8-13 yr) mothers. These differences were independent of age-specific differences in clutch size. Maternal age did not influence either the exact or relative timing of offspring recruitment; natal year had a strong effect. The proportion of sibling recruits varied annually from 0-33%. About 35% of all recruits were produced by <20% of mothers. -from Authors

dc:title: Adult size variation in two co-occurring grasshopper species in a sand-dune habitat
dc:creator: Atkinson D.
dc:description: Large adults of Chorthippus brunneus and Myrmeleotettix maculatus produce large clutches and, in M. maculatus, large eggs. Adults were larger in both 1981 and 1982 at a sheltered sand-dune site than at an exposed one nearby, and these were larger than adults at another site less than 1.3 km inland. Both sexes were larger in 1982 than in 1981. Sites and years with earlier-emerging adults had larger adults. Also, in 1982, within all populations of M. maculatus, and within one populaiton of C. brunneus, earlier-emerging individuals were larger than later ones. Early hatching of rapid growth of young nymphs (possibly associated with high temperatures and levels of grass N) is probably mainly responsible for the large size and early adult emergence. -from Authors

dc:title: Individual decisions and the distribution of predators in a patchy environment
dc:creator: Bernstein C.
dc:description: Although various relative densities are explored, the authors mostly attend to environments where prey density is approximately one order of magnitude higher than predator density. Predators are assumed to follow the rule of abandoning their current patch when local capture rate is lower than estimated capture rate in the environment as a whole. This rule maximizes long-term capture rate in many foraging situations. After abandoning a patch, predators arrive at random at any patch in the environment. Predators detect precisely the capture rate in their current patch but "learn' about the environmental average. The relative weight of past and present capture rate is controlled by a parameter denominated the "memory factor'. In the absence of depletion, the predators distribute themselves close to the predictions of the Ideal Free Distribution model. This result indicates that the IFD prediction is not dependent on assuming omniscient predation, but can be jointly derived from reasonable assumptions about learning and optimal foraging at individual level. When the environment depletes as a consequence of predation, cumulative prey mortality can be positively or negatively density-dependent, depending on the interaction between predator efficiency and the velocity of the learning process as determined by the memory factor. The learning model converges towards the IFD faster than "omniscient' variants in which the predators, instead of using a learned estimate and migrating "blindly' to any patch, use the true environmental average for the migration decision and migrate only to patches with capture rate higher than their current capture rate. Both spatial and temporal between-patch variance in prey density affect the behaviour of the model. from Authors

dc:title: Effects of adult meadow voles, Microtus pennsylvanicus, on young conspecifics in field populations
dc:creator: Rodd F.
dc:description: Adults were removed from experimental grids as follows: 1) all breeding males (female grid); 2) all breeding females (male grid); 3) most adults throughout the autumn, winter and spring (autumn-removal grid); and 4) most adults throughout the spring (spring-removal grid). All manipulations were repeated the following year. Survival, ages at sexual maturity and reproductive rates were significantly improved in young individuals, especially young females, on all experimental grids except the female grid. The demography of young animals on the female grid was either similar to that on the control grid or intermediate between that on the control grid and that on the other experimental grids. For young females, there was a significant, negative relationship between adult density and each of these parameters; for young males, only survival rates of very young animals were negatively related to adult density. Individual growth rates were not influenced by any of the manipulations. Adult animals, especially adult females, thus play a major role in limiting the density and fitness of young individuals. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of dispersal date on winter flock establishment and social dominance in marsh tits Parus palustris
dc:creator: Nilsson J.
dc:description: When sex was accounted for, time of establishment in the winter flock-range (prior occupancy) was critical for the outcome of later aggressive interactions between juveniles within flocks. Residents won all interactions with intruders irrespective of age, controlling for sex. A lower proportion of late-hatched than early-hatched juveniles became established in winter flocks; they also became established later. Since early establishment depends on early hatching, dominance and survival of the juveniles are determined by how early their parents start breeding. There will be strong selection for quick establishment after independence. -from Authors

dc:title: Habitat diversity or area per se? Species richness of woody plants, carabid beetles and land snails on islands
dc:creator: Nilsson S.
dc:description: Examined patterns of species richness of woody plants, carabid beetles and land snails on 17 undisturbed forested islands (area range 0.6-75 ha) in Lake Malaren, Sweden, in relation to area, isolation, vegetation structure, habitat diversity, habitat heterogeneity and other factors. Slopes of the species-area relations (z-values in the power model S = cAz) are 0.10 for woody plants, 0.16 for land snails, 0.36 for carabid beetles, and 0.62 for forest birds. The z-values differ significantly from zero and also differ between all organism groups except woody plants and land snails on the one hand, and land snails and carabid beetles on the other. Island area is the best single predictor of species richness in the organism groups examined. Since habitat variables and island area are uncorrelated on the studied islands, one can reject the habitat diversity hypothesis as an explanation for the species-area relations found. Total densities of woody plants and land snails were not correlated with island area; total density of carabids was positively correlated with island area. Islands with a high proportion of wet forests have relatively higher species richness of carabids, and the number of land snail species relates positively to the proportion of deciduous forest. -from Authors

dc:title: Searching for density-dependent regulation in a population of pied flycatchers Ficedula hypoleuca Pallas
dc:creator: Stenning M.
dc:description: Breeding data from a population of pied flycatchers nesting from 1948-1964 in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire, were analysed. High breeding population densities followed seasons in which many young were fledged, but the increased numbers of breeding birds resulted from high levels of immigration as well as from increased recruitment of birds raised in the study area in the previous breeding season. When nestling mortality was high, a smaller proportion of birds breeding in the area the following year were immigrants. During the first 7 yr of the study, high breeding population densities were associated with small clutch sizes. Nestling mortality was not correlated with breeding population densities. The number of birds in the study area at the end of the breeding season accounted for c76% of the variation in rates of return of 1st yr birds to breed in the area the following year, with a lower proportion of birds returning following high-density years. -from Authors

dc:title: Life history of the land snail Arianta arbustorum along an altitudinal gradient
dc:creator: Baur B.
dc:description: The altitudinal gradient was from 1220-2600 m in the Swiss Alps. Adult snails size decreased from 19.9 to 16.0 mm (mean shell breadth) with increasing altitude, age at maturity increased from 1.9 to 5.0 yr, but median adult longevity and adult survival rates were about the same at all altitudes. Clutch number, clutch size, egg size and reproductive investment per year decreased with increasing altitude, whereas reproductive investment per egg increased. Within populations, clutch number, number of eggs produced per year and egg size scaled allometrically with shell size indicating a size-specific fecundity. Although proximate factors like temperature explain most of the variation in life history, evidence was obtained also for genetic divergence among populations. Results match the predictions of the adversity selection model well. -from Authors

dc:title: Space use and reproductive success in a population of meadow voles
dc:creator: Ostfeld R.S.
dc:description: A population of Microtus pennsylvanicus was studied in South Natick, Massachusetts. Males had significantly larger home ranges, in late August-early September, and showed significantly greater intrasexual overlap than did females. Seven of 13 radiotracked females and 3 of 17 males produced offspring which survived to trappable age. Each of the 7 successful mothers had a smaller home range than any of the unsuccessful females, but this difference was not due simply to the presence of dependent young in the successful females' nests; during the radiotracking period, some of the successful females were not lactating while some of the unsuccessful females were. There was tendency, albeit not statistically significant, for successful mothers to have less intrasexual overlap than unsuccessful females. For males, there was no relationship between breeding success and either home range size or intrasexual overlap. Selection may be operating to cause divergent patterns of space use between the sexes. -from Authors

dc:title: Time allocation in the kestrel (Falco tinnunculus), and the principle of energy miminization
dc:creator: Masman D.
dc:description: In the Netherlands, common vole Microtus arvalis, was the major food source for kestrel (92% of food items caught) with minor additions, especially in summer, of common shrews Sorex araneus, songbirds and juvenile waders. Flight-hunting yielded, on average, 2.2 small mammals h-1 in winter and 4.7 in summer. Perching yield dropped from 0.3 mammals h-1 in winter to below 0.1 in summer. Flight-hunting yield reflected seasonal variations in food availability, perching yield did not. There was no stage in the annual cycle where available daylight limited the daily flight-hunting time. There were no weather conditions where daily flight-hunting exceeded an average of 3.6 h or 20% of the active day. Stringent periods, in the sense that all buffer time is used for foraging, were found neither in winter, when food was scarce, nor in summer when food demand was highest. Experimentally increased hunger of the brood led to increased male parental effort in terms of time spent flight-hunting plus flying, with a recorded maximum of 60% of the active day. Flight-hunting yield did not increase. In winter, kestrels minimized energy expenditure, not foraging time, by using the low-cost low-profit technique of perch-hunting. In summer they maximized daily energy gain within limits probably set by their rate of food assimilation. -from Authors

dc:title: A model of Cadra cautella larval growth and development
dc:creator: Gordon D.
dc:description: In the stored-products moth Cadra cautella, larval survival as well as age and weight at pupation are dependent on the density at which larvae are reared. A mathematical model developed to describe larval growth and development considers the growth and development of males and females separately; larval food ingestion rate is inversely related to the amount of larval biomass per unit of food; and larval development indices are a function of larval age and weight. The model provides a good description of total food consumption, larval survival, and larval age and weight at pupation for those larval densities where food exhaustion does not occur. Although the model captures the broad effects, it overestimates the impact of food exhaustion on larval growth and development. Coprophagy and cannibalism, factors not included in the model, account for the model's departures from the observed data when food exhaustion occurs. -from Authors

dc:title: Mating success, spatial organization, and male characteristics in experimental field populations of the red-backed vole Clethrionomys rufocanus bedfordiae
dc:creator: Kawata M.
dc:description: Number of males that established home ranges did not significantly differ among enclosures, but body weight distributions of the male populations differed significantly between enclosures, and at the end of the experimental period, differed between enclosures where the body weight distributions were similar at the time of introduction. The number of females whose home range overlapped with that of a male and the number of males whose home ranges overlapped with that of a female did not differ significantly among the enclosures. The correlations between 7 male characteristics were greatest in enclosures in which variance in the body weight distribution at the time of the introduction was large. The paternity of the offspring of 29 females could be determined. Multiple paternity was found in 6 cases. Males with higher relative body weight at the time of introduction tended to mate more successfully. -from Author

dc:title: Density dependence in reproduction of the collared flycatcher (Ficedula albicollis) at high population levels
dc:creator: Torok J.
dc:description: Clutch size, number of hatched eggs and fledged young were density-independent. Flycatchers laid more eggs when the caterpillar supply was high. Reproductive success (hatching, fledging and breeding success) was density-dependent. Bad weather, especially in early spring, significantly reduced reproductive success. Flycatchers laying large clutches tended to produce smaller young at high population density. -from Authors

dc:title: Dietary responses of three raptor species to changing prey densities in a natural environment
dc:creator: Steenhof K.
dc:description: In the Snake River Birds of Prey Area, SW Idaho, jack rabbit Lepus californicus were the principal prey of golden eagle Aquila chrysaetos; Townsend's ground squirrel Spermophilus townsendii were the main prey of prairie falcon Falco mexicanus and red-tailed hawk Buteo jamaicensis. Prairie falcons had the most specialized diets, red-tailed hawks the most diverse. None of the raptor diets reflected the relative abundance of prey types in the environment. Diet diversity of each of the three raptor species expanded as the abundance of their main prey declined. Eagle preference for jack rabbits was strong and unaffected by changes in prey densities. Red-tailed hawk selectivity for jack rabbits was inversely related to ground squirrel abundance, suggesting "switching' behaviour. Prairie falcon selectivity for ground squirrels did not vary with ground squirrel densities. Prey choice was generally consistent with predictions of the original optimal diet model, but red-tailed hawk prey selection appeared to depend on relative prey densities. -from Authors

dc:title: Population biology of snowshoe hares. II. Interactions with winter food plants
dc:creator: Smith J.
dc:description: Lepus americanus were studied in winter during a cyclic fluctuation in numbers at Kluane, Yukon, 1977-1985. Betula glandulosa, the most preferred species, was common on only 4 of 9 study plots. Salix glauca was eaten most often in mid-winter, when Betula was covered by snow. Where Betula was absent, Salix was eaten at or above the level expected from its relative abundance. Picea glauca was generally not preferred, but was eaten, especially where Betula was absent. Shepherdia canadensis was eaten 4th most often. By the peak of the cycle in winter 1981-82, hares had removed much of the biomass of small twigs of Betula and Salix from 3 study plots. Hares had little effect on the biomass of Picea twigs. The biomass of these species on 2 control plots at the end of the 1981-82 winter was still sufficient to support hares. Hares browsed an average of 63% of Betula twigs, 26% of Salix twigs, 20% of Shepherdia twigs, and 14% of Picea twigs in the winter during the 3 yr of peak density. Twigs within 50 cm of the ground were browsed most often. Heavily-browsed Betula bushes grew new twigs rapidly after hare numbers had declined. Salix showed less terminal regrowth, but produced stump sprouts. Adult hares became heavier in spring as numbers rose, and then lighter as their numbers declined. Growth rates of juvenile hares in summer and autumn declined as hare numbers rose, but did so more slowly on plots where food was added. -from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of small mammals in urban habitats. II. Demography and dispersal
dc:creator: Dickman C.R.
dc:description: Demographic parameters were compared in two species of rodents, Apodemis sylvaticus and Clethrionomys glareolus, in 3 marginal (disturbed by humans) and 3 contrasting, good quality (undisturbed) habitat patches within Oxford. Population densities of both species, and survival and residency of A. sylvaticus, were greater in the undisturbed patches. Most adults of both species achieved reproductive condition during summer, but a smaller percentage of sub-adults bred in the undisturbed than in the disturbed patches. Long-distance movements between patches (100-500 m) were made principally by juveniles and sub-adults. For animals that moved between patches, minimum monthly rates of movement were 104.3 m for A. sylvaticus and 79.6 m for C. glareolus. Both species re-established populations in experimentally cleared habitat patches within 6 months of removal. Dispersal of A. sylvaticus occurred mostly during the breeding season from undisturbed habitat patches, and was probably a consequence of intensified spacing behaviour between the sexes and between juveniles and older individuals. Dispersal of C. glareolus occurred throughout the year from all populations. Demographic flexibility is the major factor allowing both species of rodents to exploit urban habitat patches. -from Authors

dc:title: The relationship between juvenile survival and litter size in wild muskrats (Ondatra zibethicus)
dc:creator: Boutin S.
dc:description: Of litters samples, 55% failed to have any young to survive to weaning. The probability of failure was not dependent on litter size (3-12 neonates). Survival of young in successful litters was not significantly correlated with litter size. Survival of individuals within litters was not independent. Instead, more litters tended to disappear completely, or have a higher proportion of young survive than expected given the average survival of young. Muskrats thus do not show a simple trade-off between juvenile survival and litter size. -from Authors

dc:title: Population biology of Microtus arvalis. I. Lifetime reproductive success of solitary and grouped breeding females
dc:creator: Boyce C.
dc:description: Lifetime reproductive success was measured as the number of breeding daughters produced per lifetime in a high density population in a 0.79-ha orchard near Bayreuth, West Germany. Although grouped breeding females produced c4 more pups during the breeding seasons than did solitary breeding females, the daughters of solitary breeding females matured significantly earlier at a mean age of 13.7 days than did daughters of grouped breeding females (mean 27.4 days) and 63% survived to produce a 1st litter while only 33% of the communal young survived to breed. Solitary breeding females produced on average 2 more breeding daughters than those breeding in groups. While solitary breeding females before winter produced more breeding and more distantly dispersing offspring, grouped breeding probably has a much greater selective advantage when the survival of overwintering generations is included in the calculation of the relative reproductive success of the 2 types of females. -from Authors

dc:title: The effect of dominance and feeding method on the intake rates of oystercatchers, Haematopus ostralegus, feeding on mussels
dc:creator: Goss-Custard J.
dc:description: The interference curves of oystercatchers feeding on mussels Mytilus edulis were measured in a sample of 40 individually-marked birds of which 15 usually opened mussels by stabbing between the valves, 13 hammered a hole in the dorsal shell and 12 in the ventral surface. In all feeding method groups, intake rate at low densities of birds ("interference-free intake rate' of IFIR) was unrelated to dominance ranking, but subdominant birds were more susceptible to interference from other birds as birds density increased. Average IFIRs of dorsal and ventral hammerers were the same, and 40-50% greater than in the stabbing birds which took smaller mussels. Hammerers were more prone to interference than stabbers of the same rank, but not because they were attacked more frequently. Average density of birds on the mussel bed was 219 ha-1, sufficient to depress the average intake rate of the most subdominant hammerer by 25% below its IFIR, but of the most dominant by only 7%. Comparable values for stabbers were a reduction of 12% in the least dominant and a 13% increase in the most dominant. The effect of interference was insufficient to override the difference between the IFIRs of stabbers and hammerers, so hammereres still averaged higher intake rates in winter than stabbers. Accordingly, stabbers fed more than the hammerers on supplementary food in the fields at high water. This probably made the stabbing birds more likely to starve during cold weather when earthworms become unavailable. -from Authors

dc:title: Field measurement of the dependence of life history on plant nitrogen and temperature for a herbivorous moth
dc:creator: Taylor M.F.J.
dc:description: A generation of Samea multiplicalis (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae) was reared in field cages in each season of a year on plants with either high or low nitrogen content. Development rates of all stages were greatest at 28-30C, declining significantly at lower and sometimes higher leaf temperatures. Early larval survival declined sharply at temperatures >30C, but was largely unaffected by low temperatures. Pupal survival declined with decreasing leaf temperatures. Fecundity was greatest at air temperatures of 20-22C, and egg survival at leaf temperatures of 25-26C. Declining plant N% had pervasive effects throughout the life history: reducing larval growth rate and survival, slowing pupal development, reducing fecundity and slowing development of eggs laid, but increasing the survival of the eggs. Larval development rates were greatest at lower temperatures on lower plant N%, and the heavy early larval mortality at high temperatures was exacerbated by lower plant N%. Differences in intrinsic rate of population increase between N% treatments were greatest in higher temperatures, and least in winter temperatures. Results supported the hypothesis that the larval period was adaptively plastic rather than simply physiologically constrained. The larval development period and response of larval period to plant N% differences were significantly heritable. Intrinsic rate of population increase was highest in autumn for both low and high N% treatments, and least in summer for the low N% treatment. -from Author

dc:title: Costs of reproduction and success of manipulated broods under varying food conditions in Tengmalm's owl
dc:creator: Korpimaki E.
dc:description: Male Aegolius funereus collect nearly all the food for their females and young in the breeding season. Brood sizes of males between one year and the following year were not significantly correlated. Males rearing large broods survived only marginally better the next year than those rearing small broods. In 1985 and 1986, 1 newly hatched young was in some cases transferred between 2 nests. In control nests, one young was exchanged for one young from another brood. The proportion of males surviving and breeding in the next year was similar in the 3 groups that reared reduced, control or enlarged broods in the preceding year. Enlarged broods did not affect breeding performance in the next year. In 1985 (when the vole supply was increasing), the owls could rear enlarged broods, whereas in 1986 (vole supply decreasing), they tended to be unable to do so. In 1986 but not in 1985, fledglings in enlarged broods were slightly lighter than those in control or reduced broods. Neither correlative nor experimental data from the males supported the hypothesis of reproductive costs. The probable reason was that males given enlarged broods did not increase their reproductive effort. In the increase phase of the vole cycle, the number of coles available to the egg-laying female probably limits clutch size, whereas in the decrease phase food available during the nestling and fledging periods is even more limited. -from Author

dc:title: Feeding intensity, growth rates, and the establishment of life- history patterns in juvenile Atlantic salmon Salmo salar
dc:creator: Metcalfe N.
dc:description: Under good growing conditions, populations of juvenile Atlantic salmon develop a bimodal size-frequency distribution by late autumn of their 1st year; larger fish in the upper modal group will metamorphose into the sea-going phase the following spring, a year ahead of fish in the lower modal group. The fast and slow developing life-history patterns become fixed prior to September of the 1st year, and the corresponding changes in appetite and growth rate are thereafter under internal control. An October peak in appetite does not appear to be related to natural food availability, and may instead allow fish to obtain nutritional reserves prior to the winter when feeding is constrained. -from Authors

dc:title: Foraging effort and life span of workers in a social insect
dc:creator: Schmid-Hempel P.
dc:description: Energetically low-cost foraging strategies such as those practised by nectar-collecting workers of the honeybee Apis mellifera are considered to be adaptive if foraging effort reduces life span. Experimental results here lead to the conclusion that a reduction in the average work load below what bees accept under natural conditions would not significantly lengthen life span of workers, but that life span might be reduced if bees increased their work load. -from Authors

dc:title: Density-dependent processes and key factors in insect populations
dc:creator: Stiling P.
dc:description: Examined the frequency of different population processes acting either as key factors or as density-dependent sources of regulation on insect populations in the field, as reported in the literature, ie processes were scored as to whether they were most important in perturbing populations away from equilibrium levels (as key factors) or in acting as negative-feedback mechanisms to return populations to equilibria. Factors affecting population density covered a wide range, from parasitism and predation to starvation, reduced fecundity, and dispersal. For 58 species of insects, no single process could be regarded as a key factor of overriding importance; different sources of mortality were important in different systems. The same was true for regulatory or density-dependent mechanisms. In about half of the studies, there were no obvious density-dependent factors operating; many population densities may commonly fluctuate between an upper ceiling and a lower floor rather than be maintained around a more fixed equilibrium. Where density dependence was detected, it was more likely to be due to a source of mortality acting from the trophic level below (ie the plant) than from the trophic level above (predators and parasites). Any given type of mortality or population process was more likely to perturb densities away from a mean level than to be density-dependent and act to return populations to equilibrium. -from Author

dc:title: Feeding ecology of great tits (Parus major) and blue tits (Parus caeruleus), breeding in suburban gardens
dc:creator: Cowie R.
dc:description: Birds breeding in gardens fed their nestlings at a similar rate, and with similar sized prey, to birds breeding in woodland. There was no difference in type of prey brought by males and females in either species, but great tits brought more spiders (Araneae) and Diptera, blue tits more aphids (Hemiptera). Both species brought c15% of the nestlings' food from bird tables. There was no relationship between amount of artificial food in the diet, and nestling survival, in either species. In blue tits proportionately more spiders were fed to young nestlings (3-9 days), whilst older nestlings (14-15 days) received more artificial food and aphids. Young great tit nestlings (3-9 days) were fed greater than expected numbers of spiders, earwigs (Dermaptera) and Diptera. Blue tits brought fewer Lepidopteran larvae than expected from 07.00-16.00 h, and more aphids. Great tits brought more spiders than expected from 08.00-13.00 h, and more Diptera from 05.00-08.00 h. Both species showed a tendency to bring prey in runs. -from Authors

dc:title: Migrant passerine birds in European forest successions in relation to vegetation height and geographical position
dc:creator: Helle P.
dc:description: The proportion of trans-Saharan migrant pairs was consistently low in the tallest vegetation, highest in vegetation 1-2 m high, and higher in N and C Europe, than in S and W Europe. Vegetation height and longitude were the best predictors of the proportion of migrants; this was the case for the complete data set and for coniferous successions analysed separately. Breeding densities of migrants were greatest in the middle stages of succession at a vegetation height of 1-10 m. Five main groups of migrant assemblages were identified in terms of successional stages and region; early successional stages (vegetation height <1 m) supported distinct assemblages from the later stages with those in S Europe being strikingly different to all others. Diversity (measured by a dominance index) of migrant assemblages was lowest in W Europe and tended to be lower in late than in early successional stages. In W and S Europe the diversity of migrant assemblages was greatest where migrants were abundant relative to other species, but this did not appear to be the case in N and C Europe. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of population density and supplemental food on reproduction in song sparrows
dc:creator: Arcese P.
dc:description: Population density and reproduction in Melospiza melodia on Mandarte Island, B.C., varied widely from 1975-1986. Several measures of reproductive success declined as population density increased by 6 times. At peak density, females produced 1/4 the number of young produced at low densities. Supplemental food advanced laying date; increased clutch size, the number of breeding attempts, nestling weight and the number of independent young produced; and reduced brood parasitism and the interval between successful nesting attempts. Supplemental food was associated with reduced adult survival to the next breeding season, perhaps because of increased competition for territories with feeders after the feeding experiment. -from Authors

dc:title: Body weight and juvenile mortality in rooks Corvus frugilegus
dc:creator: Patterson I.
dc:description: Adults rooks trapped near Aberdeen, Grampian, were lighter in summer than in spring and juveniles remained lighter than adults from May until August, confirming previous suggestions of food shortage for rocks in summer. Year-to-year variations in mean weight in March and June were not related to temperature or rainfall, suggesting that there was no short-term change in weight in relation to food availability, or that these weather variables were not good predictors of rook food supply. Mean weights of adult males and females in June declined similarly as population density increased during the study; recaptured juveniles lost weight over summer at a rate which also increased with population density, possibly indicating greater competition for food with larger numbers of rooks in the area. Juveniles which survived their 1st summer were significantly heavier when first caught than those which disappeared, ie low body weight was associated with increased mortality. -from Authors

dc:title: Decline in winter moth populations in North America: direct versus indirect effect of introduced parasites
dc:creator: Roland J.
dc:description: Re-analysis of Operophtera brumata data from Nova Scotia indicates that pupal mortality, not parasitism, was the principal proximate cause of population decline. Data from a recent introduction in British Columbia also implicate pupal mortality as the major cause of population decline, not introduced parasites. Predation by beetle larvae is the major cause of pupal mortality in British Columbia. In both populations, pupal mortality does not rise until after parasitoid introduction, this rise probably resulting from the interaction of parasitism and predation on pupae. The indirect effect of parasitism, through its interaction with predation, may be far more important in successful control of winter moth than is the direct effect of adding mortality. -Author

dc:title: Inversely density-dependent parasitism: the role of plant refuges for hosts
dc:creator: Price P.
dc:description: The parasitoid was Pteromalus sp. and the host was a stem-galling sawfly, Euura lasiolepis on willow Salix lasiolepis. The pararisoid responded in an inversely density-dependent manner to host density, as density varied among patches of hosts on willow clones. There was a systematic positive relationship between mean gall diameter per willow clone and host density, such that hosts in high population patches were better concealed from parasitoids than hosts in low population patches. The size of the refuge from parasitoid attack increased as host density increased. The negative relationship between mean gall diameter per willow clone and percentage parasitism was significant. -from Author

dc:title: Egg hatching and resource partitioning in stoneflies (Plecoptera): ten British species in the family Nemouridae
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: Compared variations in egg hatching between 3 Protonemura spp., 2 Amphinemura spp., Nemurella pictetii and 4 Nemoura spp. (interspecific variations) and between populations of each species (intraspecific variations). There were significant interspecific, but not intraspecific, differences in female sizes, adult life-span and egg production. Interspecific differences in egg development in the ten species are related to their different larval habitats and flight periods (months in which adults are present). These differences ensure a continual succession of species throughout the year and a reduction in competition between closely-related species; this reduction being almost total for the cold-water stenotherms and species living in still or very slow running water, but only partial for the remaining species. -from Author

dc:title: Population regulation, density dependence, and heterogeneity
dc:creator: Mountford M.D.
dc:description: A mathematical model of a univoltine insect herbivore population incorporating non-random dispersal of adults and larval density dependence is constructed to examine whether the detection of density dependence is obscured by spatial and stochastic heterogeneity. For a given mean size of the equilibrium population spatial heterogeneity enhances the detection of density dependence. For a given mean size of the equilibrium population stochastic heterogeneity is neutral in its effect. Detailed analysis of within-generation instar mortality does not always suffice in detecting density dependence. -from Author

dc:title: Population biology of Microtus arvalis. II. Natal and breeding dispersal of females
dc:creator: Boyce C.
dc:description: Breeding dispersal occurred only in solitary breeding females within 24 h pre-partum when both grouped and solitary breeding females built a new nest either within the same burrow (residents) or 16-537 m from their burrow (dispersers). Solitary females provided with large artificial nest sites dispersed significantly less frequently than females provided with small artificial nest sites or living at small natural burrows. Natal dispersal occurred on the 1st day that a vagina could be identified and in 11 females was concomitant with matings leading to a 1st litter. Littermates settled in the same areas. Breeding dispersal was a consequence of soil hardness which frustrated the extension of existing burrows and proximately resulted from rises of oestrogen levels at pre-partum which initiates nest building. In contrast, natal dispersal in females was the rule and was related to 1st mating. The costs of breeding and natal dispersal at high population density in terms of surviving to produce a 1st litter were negligible. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal food shortage, weight loss, and the timing of births in saddle-back tamarins (Saguinus fuscicollis)
dc:creator: Goldizen A.W.
dc:description: Saguinus fuscicollis (Callitrichidae) were studied in the Cocha Cashu Biological Station, Manu National Park, Peru. Availability of both fruits and insects was substantially lower during the annual 4-month dry season (May-September) than at other times of the year. Individual tamarins lost an average of 5% of their weight over this period. Three-quarters of births occurred between November and February; none occurred between mid-March and mid-August. Tamarin births at Cocha Cashu are probably timed such that lactation and weaning occur when food is abundant, because during the period of low food availability, there would be insufficient food to meet the demands of lactation and to serve as easily obtainable weaning foods. -from Authors

dc:title: Arthropod predation in an Antarctic terrestrial community
dc:creator: Lister A.
dc:description: Predation by the mite Gamasellus racovitzai on 3 other species of micro-arthropods was determined at Signy Island. During summer, c85% of the predator population had detectable prey traces. The species composition of these traces in Gamasellus from 3 major habitat types reflected the proportions of prey observed in the field community, although there were differences between the life-stages of Gamasellus. The collembolan Cryptopygus antarcticus formed c80% of all prey traces. The non-feeding component of the predatory population was stable at c14% despite the 10-fold range in Cryptopygus densities between moss-turf, fellfield and ornithogenic sites. There was no detectable functional response over a 300-fold range in prey density. Results of laboratory experiments on attack rate on different size classes of prey are discussed. -from Authors

dc:title: Population biology of Microtus arvalis. III. Regulation of numbers and breeding dispersion of females
dc:creator: Boyce C.
dc:description: Density fluctuated between a maximum of 1333 voles ha-1 in July 1980 and a minimum of 24 voles ha-1 in April 1982. Females bred in groups or solitarily. At all densities, mean group size was 3. At high density most females bred solitarily. Females had greatly overlapping 10-day home ranges but only grouped females used common areas at the same time. Grouped females occurred at large complex burrows which contained food caches, nest chambers, earth-filled escape tunnels and c10 exit tunnels. Large burrows were in soft soil. Solitary females occurred at sites with hard soil and built small burrows in anthills (74% of nest sites) or at the base of rocks and trees. These burrows contained 1 nest chamber, no food caches, no escape tunnels, and <4 exit tunnels. The large burrows of grouped females were the preferred nest sites; grouped females excluded neighbouring solitary females from their burrow. The observed spacing behaviour did not cause mortality, reproductive inhibition, or dispersal but limited immigration to groups. Group size of breeding females was limited by dispersal of sexually maturing young and by spacing behaviour. -from Authors

dc:title: The edge of the range
dc:creator: Caughley G.
dc:description: Suggests a theoretical framework for considering limits to relatively stable distributions and illustrates some of the points raised with information on the distribution of 2 species of kangaroos. If an attribute such as density or condition is low at the periphery but rises progressively towards the core of the distribution, its trend is described as a "ramp'. If the level of the attribute differs little between the periphery and the core of the distribution its trend forms a "step" at the range boundary. Should density form a ramp inwards from the boundary whereas the mean well-being of the animals (eg body condition, growth, weight, recruitment) forms a step, the factor limiting distribution is likely to be a resource that is utilized consumptively or pre-emptively. Should both density and well-being form a ramp, the implicated factor is a component of climate, an unmodifiable resource, or a facultative predator, parasite or pathogen. Should both density and well-being step at the range boundary, the factor controlling the position of the boundary is likely to be the substrate. Western grey kangaroo Macropus fuliginosus exhibited a ramp of both density and well-being which, in combination with ecological information, suggested that the edge of the range was positioned by a component of climate perhaps interacting with an unmodifiable resource. Eastern grey kangaroo M. giganteus exhibited a ramp of density but a step of well-being, implicating a renewable resource as the factor determining the inland boundary of distribution. Density and distribution are likely to be different aspects of the same thing except where the limiting factor or combination of factors is or includes a renewable resource consumed by the animals. -from Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics of common and rare helminths in cyclic vole populations
dc:creator: Haukisalmi V.
dc:description: Population dynamics of vole helminths in Finnish Lapland were studied for a 10 yr period covering a peak phase of a vole cycle (1977-78), an entire cycle (1980-85), and an increase phase of a third cycle (1968-87). The host material consists of bank vole Clethrionomys glareolus and red voles Clethrionomys rutilus. Common helminths (Heligmosomum mixtum, Nematoda, and Catenotaenia sp., Cestoda) were characeterized by regular seasonal changes in prevalence and intensity, with peak of infection occurring in winter. Generally, density of C. glareolus did not determine infection levels, but during the low and increase phase of a typical vole cycle the prevalence of common helminths followed those of the host. Rare species (Mastophorus muris, Capillaria sp., Syphacia petrusewiczi, Nematoda, and Paranoplocephala kalelai, Cestoda) showed different seasonal dynamics with a spring, summer or autumn peak in overwintered voles. Multi-annually they were less predictable than the common species, and dynamics were not affected by the phases of low host density, probably because of their strictly seasonal occurrence and, consequently, long response times. Regulation of common helminths seemed to be accomplished primarily at the level of host individuals, the role of the hosts' immunological mechanisms being important. Transmission was impaired only when extremely low host densities prevailed for long periods of time. No evidence of host mortality caused by common helminths was found. Stochastic factors affecting the survival of infective stages, and hence transmission, may be more important for rare than common species. The life histories (modes of feeding and reproduction, life cycles) of vole helminths did not determine the nature of their population dynamics and regulation, but common species were characterized by a low degree of aggregation, whereas all the rare nematodes were highly aggregated within the host population. -from Authors

dc:title: Analysis of counts from monitoring guillemots in Britain and Ireland
dc:creator: Rothery P.
dc:description: This analysis of monitoring data is based on 27 British and Irish colonies where individual Uria aalge were counted repeatedly in clearly defined areas of cliff (plots) 1975-82. In general, numbers at colonies in N Scotland and NE Britain increased from 1975 to 1982, but some Welsh and Irish colonies decreased. At 13 of the 22 colonies with significant long-term trends there was significant year-to-year variation about the trend. Much of this variation seemed haphazard but there was some evidence of a general slowing down in the rate of increase towards the end of the period. Within-year variation of counts was measured using the coefficient of variation (standard deviation expressed as a percentage of the mean). For plots containing 200 or more birds the value was usually 8-9%. -from Authors

dc:title: Movement ecology of the red milkweed beetle in relation to population size and structure
dc:creator: Lawrence W.
dc:description: Tetraopes tetraophthalmus abundance, but not beetle density per plant, was correlated with host-plant patch size. Beetle sex ratios differ between days and between patches, changing the relative abundance of potential mates within and between subpopulations. Male residency is less than female residency. Average age of males, however, is significantly greater than females. This results from males 2-6 days old being underrepresented in the population. Males move significantly farther between recaptures than females both within and between host-plant patches. Males also move between host-plant patches significantly more frequently. Males obtain high levels of mobility much more rapidly than females. The age of individuals moving between patches is significantly greater than that of individuals moving within patches. Males are particularly responsive to sex ratio and conspecific abundance, leaving patches where sex ratios are male biased. -from Author

dc:title: Species diversity in the third and fourth trophic levels: patterns and mechanisms
dc:creator: Hawkins B.
dc:description: Parasitoid lists generated from the primary literature for 285 species of British phytophagous insects were used to examine correlates of parasitoid species-richness patterns. The number of parasitoid species supported by a herbivore was tested against 8 variables describing taxonomic and ecological characteristics of hosts. Herbivore feeding niche and host-plant architecture were major determinants of parasitoid richness. Geographic range/extent studied, herbivore host-plant specificity, host taxonomic isolation and the number of generations per year (for Lepidoptera) had statistically significant effects on richness, but were judged to be of questionable biological importance. -from Author

dc:title: A 13-year study of the population dynamics and growth of the European eel Anguilla anguilla in a Norwegian river: evidence for density-dependent mortality, and development of a model for predicting yield
dc:creator: Vollestad L.
dc:description: In the Imsa River, SW Norway mean age of the descending silver eels was 7.9 yr; there was a significant relationship between number of elvers ascending and silver eels descending 8 yr later. The weak 1979 year-class could be recognized in the age-distribution samples. Instantaneous rate of total mortality based on age data varied from 0.088-0.225 for the 5 year-classes, and the mortality rate for 1975-1987 was estimated at 0.167 based on mean ascent and descent data. Numbers of ascending elvers varied strongly, and was significantly related to water temperature. Survival rate of eels in fresh water was density-dependent. The sex ratio (males/females) varied from 0.010-0.075, but this variation could not be explained by variation in elver numbers or by variation in eel density in the river during the first summer. Back-calculated growth rate of male silver eels and female silver eels >7 yr old was close to the growth rate of yellow eels of the same age. Females grew faster when they transformed at a younger age. Instantaneous growth rate for weight decreased from 1.4 the first season in fresh water to 0.2 for the 7th growth season onwards. Mean annual production in the system was 3.51 kg ha-1; mean yield was 2.27 kg ha-1. -from Authors

dc:title: Lifetime reproductive output of male and female meadow pipits Anthus pratensis
dc:creator: Hotker H.
dc:description: During a 12-yr population study in NW Germany, the number of recruits descended from individual meadow pipits was significantly correlated with the number of (ringed) fledglings they produced, implying that lifetime reproductive output was a good measure of individual fitness. Males produced an average of 6.06, females an average of 6.03, fledglings during their lifetime (probably slight underestimates). The proportion of males failing completely or producing very many offspring were significantly higher than in females. Longevity had more influence on lifetime reproduction than mean annual production. A significant correlation between habitat quality and lifetime reproduction was only found for males. -from Author

dc:title: Host effects on larval competition in the gregarious Bracon hebetor
dc:creator: Taylor A.
dc:description: Describes the effects of host species and size on larval competition, survival and development in the gregarious parasitoid Bracon hebetor (Hymenoptera: Braconidae). Wasp eggs were placed at a range of densities on 3 sizes of 2 host species Anagasta kuhniella and Plodia interpunctella (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae) and the number, sex, size, and date of emerging adults were recorded. The mean size of emerging adults was strongly density-dependent, and "carrying capacity' was linearly related to host mass, both within and across host species. Survival also was density-dependent on the smaller host species, and on the larger species when very high densities were used. Competition among these parasitoids thus appears to be largely determined by the amount of food which the host constitutes. Survival was lower on small hosts of both species, independent of density. Also, Plodia hosts from some cultures were unsuitable (produced no parasitoids), independent of size and density. Development time was unaffected by egg density or host size, and only very slightly by host species. -from Author

dc:title: Effects of territory quality on occupancy, breeding performance and breeding dispersal in Tengmalm's owl
dc:creator: Korpimaki E.
dc:description: Aegolius funereus territories in W Finland were graded according to frequency of use in over 10 yr: from 0 (not used), to 5 (used in 5-9 yr). On good territories the proportion of pine forest was small, and the proportions of spruce forest and agricultural land were large. Densities of small mammal prey are lower in pine forest than in spruce forest, where small mammal populations are also rather stable. Microtus voles occupy agricultural land and show predictable population cycles. Thus, owls on good territories benefit from vole peaks by foraging over farmland and shift to alternative prey in woodland during the low phase of the vole cycle. Poor territories supported a breeding pair only in peak vole years, but good ones also in low vole years. Independently of their age both females and males performed better on grades 4-5 than on grades 2-3. Nearly all females shifted territories between successive breeding attempts, but males stayed on the same territory after their 1st breeding attempt. Females seemed to move to get more experienced mates rather than better territories. The longevity of males was greater on grades 4-5 than on grades 2-3. Mean longevity of males on their tertitories was 1.6 yr. Some good territories became vacant every year, but males did not change territories. Because of a scarcity of nest-holes, there are few possibilities for finding a new, good territory with sutiable nest-hole(s). -from Author

dc:title: Growth, size, biomass and production in contrasting populations of trout Salmo trutta in two Lake District streams
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: Resident brown trout in Wilfin Beck were smaller than migratory trout of similar age in Black Brows Beck. Mean sizes and growth rates for different life stages varied considerably between year-clases in both populations; they were not density-dependent. Water temperature and fry weight were the chief factors affecting growth in the first 3 yr of the life cycle in Wilfin Beck and all the freshwater phase in Black Brows Beck. Food was only a limiting factor for the first autumn-spring period of the life cycle and for adults > 3 yr old in Wilfin Beck. Variation in individual size was inversely density-dependent in Black Brows Beck and decreased with age in Wilfin Beck. Fish biomass at the end of the summer in Wilfin Beck (mean for 1966-72, 7.9 g m-2) was c60% that in Black Brows Beck (mean for 1967-83, 13.0 g m-2), but annual production in Wilfin Beck (mean 6.1 g m-2) was only c25% that in Black Brows Beck (mean 24.4 g m-2). Migratory behaviour ensured that larger trout did not remain to use resources such as food and space in Black Brows Beck, whereas these older trout remained in Wilfin Beck, forming a major part of the biomass whilst contributing little to annual production. Smaller fry size at the start of the growth period, not lack of food, was chiefly responsible for the smaller trout in Wilfin Beck. The larger fry size in Black Brows Beck was related directly to egg weight which, in turn, was related to the larger spawning females and to a higher proportion of the female's resources being invested in egg production (30-37% of female's total energy content in Black Brows Beck, 16-17% in Wilfin Beck). -from Author

dc:title: Reproductive costs in two sex-role reversed pipefish species (Syngnathidae)
dc:creator: Svensson I.
dc:description: In Syngnathus typhle, males brood their offspring in a brood pouch, providing them with nutrients and oxygen. Sexes are monomorphic. Males faced reproductive costs in terms of a lower food intake compared with females. Also, males grew more slowly than females, which yields a cost to future reproduction, as larger males could brood more offspring. No sexual difference in predation risk was found. Over-winter survival of males was probably lowered because intestinal fat deposition was delayed as a result of their reproductive efforts. In Nerophis ophidion, males brood their offspring attached to their ventral body side, and provide them with nutrients and oxygen. Sexes are dimorphic, females being larger and bright in colour. Males suffered an increased predation risk when brooding. No indications of energetic costs were found, eg through lowered food intake or slower growth rate. Reproductive costs differed in the two species, probably reflecting differences in brood care, but in both species the limiting sex, males, faced higher reproductive costs than females, as would be expected in sex-role reversed animals. -from Author

dc:title: The influence of weather and biotic factors on the behaviour of the scorpion (Paruroctonus utahensis)
dc:creator: Bradley R.
dc:description: This abundant arthropophagous predator in central New Mexico grasslands is a strictly nocturnal sit-and-wait predator. Individuals spend only a small proportion of apparently suitable nights foraging on the surface; the remainder are spent in a deep burrow. Daily variation in surface activity levels were partially explained by climatic factors during spring and autumn. Environmental factors exert a major influence over the type of behaviour exhibited by scorpions. The hypothesis that the time-minimization strategy employed has evolved in response to predation pressure remains the most likely explanation for the variable patterns of emergence. -from Author

dc:title: Survival rate in the great tit Parus major in relation to sex, age, and immigration status
dc:creator: Clobert J.
dc:description: In Wytham Wood, Oxfordshire, some birds seem to miss 1 yr of breeding in nestboxes more often than others; these are more likely to be immigrants. Age, sex, and immigration status of the birds have a strong influence on survival rate. Male survival rate is negatively related to density of blue tits, while that of females is not. This may be related to the cost of defending a territory. Female survival rate is negatively related to the beech crop production of the previous year, which is probably an indirect measure of the number of resident males, so that the relationship reflects competition between males and females. Survival rates of immigrant males and resident females are affected by different variables from those affecting resident males and immigrant females. These differences may be related to sex differences in dispersal behaviour. In any year, females may survive better or worse than males and independently immigrants may survive better or worse than residents. These differences in survival between groups are not consistent in direction, although sometimes strongly significant. -from Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics of the avocet (Recurvirostra avosetta) breeding in Britain
dc:creator: Hill D.
